properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall: local snowfall possibly reaching 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 60 km/h causing blowing snow. Locations: Inverness county - south of Mabou, Victoria county, Pictou county, Antigonish county, and Kings county, Prince Edward Island. Time frame: From this afternoon to Sunday afternoon. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-08T11:17:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-07T19:18:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2040075534.2019
Area: Pictou County, Antigonish County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Victoria County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall: locally 10 to 15 cm to possibly 30 cm over the Highlands. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 60 km/h causing blowing snow. Locations: Western Cape Breton, including the Highlands, Pictou and Antigonish counties, and Kings county, Prince Edward Island. Timespan: From this afternoon to Sunday afternoon. Remarks: Flurries and risk of snowsqualls are forecast to develop this afternoon and continue through tonight and Sunday morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-08T06:45:12-00:00

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Southerly winds will reach up to 90 kilometres per hour beginning this morning. Winds will diminish in the late afternoon. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A frontal system crossing the BC Interior will continue to give snow to the region tonight. The snow will end early Saturday as the front moves southward. About 10 to 15 cm of snow is forecast for many locations south of Prince George, over the Stuart-Nechako region including Vanderhoof and south, and for southern sections of the Lakes District including Ootsa Lake. For the area near Quesnel, communities closer to the Cariboo Mountains and along parts of the Yellowhead Highway, 15 to 25 cm of snow is possible by Saturday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-07T22:05:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-07T06:06:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2396431342.2019
Area: Cariboo - north including Quesnel, Yellowhead, Lakes District, Stuart - Nechako, Prince George, McGregor
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Pacific frontal system crossing the central coast early this morning will give an additional accumulation of up to 5 cm. The snow will end this morning as the front moves out of the region. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Possible snowfall amounts: up to 15 cm in snow squalls. Location: Corner Brook to Port aux Basques. Time span: this evening to Sunday afternoon. Remarks: Onshore flurries and occasional snow squalls are expected to develop this evening and persist until Sunday afternoon. Poor visibilities can be expected within the snow squalls. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has issued an Air Quality Advisory for Vanderhoof and Fort St. John due to high concentrations of fine particulate matter. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. If you are experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, follow the advice of your health care provider. Staying indoors and in air conditioned spaces helps to reduce fine particulate exposure. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-12-08T04:55:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2019-12-07T12:56:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3303987771.2019
Area: B.C. North Peace River, Stuart - Nechako
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 60 to 80 km/h. Locations: Postville - Makkovik. Time span: until Sunday morning. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will continue tonight before tapering off Sunday morning. A strong northerly wind will accompany the snow tonight resulting in reduced visibilities, at times near zero, in blowing snow. Conditions will improve Sunday morning as the snow tapers and winds diminish. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-08T11:40:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-07T19:41:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3097402663.2019
Area: Postville - Makkovik
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow is falling in west-central parts of the province. The snow is expected to gradually move southwards today and is forecast to end from north to south beginning early Sunday morning. In the Crowsnest Pass region, snow is expected to begin early this evening with the highest snowfall amounts focused near Waterton Lakes National Park. In the Cypress Hills region, snow is forecast to begin this evening, with the more intense band of snow moving through the region overnight. General amounts of 10 to 20 cm are forecast, although amounts may reach 30 cm in localized areas near the B.C. and Canada-USA border. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-08T09:24:29-00:00

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Additional snowfall amounts: 5 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northerly at 60 km/h. Locations: Hopedale and vicinity. Time span: until early Sunday morning. Remarks: Fresh snowfall will combine with strong northerly winds tonight to produce poor visibility in blowing snow. The snow will taper off overnight tonight and winds will ease early Sunday morning. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Summary:

Further snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 cm are expected before the front moves out of the region. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain continues eastwards along the Trans-Canada Highway corridor with most areas seeing 1 to 2 hours of freezing rain mixed with snow at times before tapering off. Liquid accumulations of 0.5 to 2 mm are likely, with variable amounts of that contributing to ice accumulation based on location and pre-existing surface treatments. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-07T22:29:40-00:00

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. A weak disturbance crossing northern Yukon will give strong east winds of 50 km/h gusting to 70 near the Richardson Mountains overnight and Sunday morning. These strong winds will give reduced visibility in blowing snow and cold wind chills near minus 30. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-08T04:12:32-00:00
